remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Hello, thank you for coming in today. I’d like to start by understanding more about your symptoms—can you tell me when you first noticed any difficulty with your breathing or signs of hypoxia, such as shortness of breath or low oxygen levels?

remedi_labels.value: signs of hypoxia such as shortness of breath or low oxygen levels

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um... I guess the main thing is I’ve been feeling kind of short of breath lately. It’s been a little hard to catch my breath, and I feel uncomfortable. And, uh, my leg’s been hurting too. Should I be worried?

I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—shortness of breath and leg pain can be concerning symptoms. To help me with my assessment, can you describe if your shortness of breath comes on suddenly or if it’s been gradually getting worse over the past few days?

remedi_labels.value: onset and progression of shortness of breath

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, I think it’s been kind of gradual. I just noticed I was more out of breath than usual, and then it started feeling worse. I saw on my chart they mentioned hypoxia—should I be worried about that? I’m just feeling pretty uncomfortable.

I can understand why you’d be worried about experiencing short of breath and uncomfortable—those symptoms can be distressing. To help with my assessment, have you noticed if your breathing has become more rapid than usual, or if you’ve been breathing faster even at rest?

Well, um… now that you mention it, I think I have been breathing faster than usual, even when I’m just sitting. It’s like I can’t quite catch my breath. And, uh, I’ve also been feeling kind of sleepy—like, somnolent, I guess is the word? I’m not sure if that’s related, but it’s been happening more lately. Is that something to be concerned about?

remedi_labels.value: Is that something to be concerned about?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious about experiencing more sleepy and noticing faster breathing—those symptoms are important for us to assess. To help guide my clinical evaluation, have you experienced any confusion, difficulty staying awake, or changes in your alertness along with the somnolence?

Let me think… I guess I have felt a little more confused than usual, and sometimes it’s hard to stay awake. Actually, there’s something else—I’ve noticed some involuntary movements in my right arm, like it kind of jerks on its own. And my left arm has been swelling up a bit too. I’m really not sure if all these symptoms are connected, but it’s making me pretty uncomfortable.

I can understand how confusing and uncomfortable these symptoms must feel, especially with the changes in your alertness and new involuntary movements. To help with my assessment, have you experienced any episodes where you completely lost consciousness or had difficulty responding to people around you during these periods of somnolence?

remedi_labels.value: changes in alertness and new involuntary movements
episodes of complete loss of consciousness or difficulty responding during somnolence

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… I don’t think I’ve completely lost consciousness, but there have been times where it’s hard for me to respond or stay awake, like you said. It’s almost like I’m drifting in and out a bit. And actually, now that I think about it, I’ve had some fevers lately—sometimes I get chills and start shivering, and then I’ll break out in a sweat, like diaphoresis, I guess. I just feel really uncomfortable and I’m not sure what’s causing all of this.

remedi_labels.value: drifting in and out of consciousness
not sure what’s causing all of this

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Thank you for sharing these additional symptoms—it helps guide my assessment. Given your reports of tachypnea and somnolence, have you noticed any changes in your ability to perform daily activities or any new weakness since these symptoms began?

remedi_labels.value: changes in ability to perform daily activities

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Actually, yes—I’ve definitely had more trouble doing my usual activities since all these symptoms started. I feel weaker, and it’s harder to get around, especially with the leg pain and swelling in my left arm. I get tired so quickly, and sometimes I just have to sit down because I feel so worn out.

And, um… there’s something else I wanted to mention. I’ve had a few episodes of what I think you’d call “coffee ground emesis”—I threw up and it looked dark, kind of like coffee grounds. That really worried me, especially with the fevers and chills I’ve been having. Is that something serious? I just want to feel better.

I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with symptoms like coffee ground emesis and increasing weakness. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any episodes of chest pain, palpitations, or worsening shortness of breath during these periods of tachypnea?

Let me think… I haven’t really had any chest pain, but sometimes my heart feels like it’s beating a little faster—maybe that’s what you mean by palpitations? And yes, the shortness of breath definitely gets worse when I’m breathing faster, especially if I try to move around or even just stand up. It’s all just making me feel so tired and uncomfortable.

Is all of this connected somehow? Should I be really worried about the coffee ground emesis and these other symptoms? I just want to know what’s going on and if there’s something you can do to help me feel better.

remedi_labels.value: shortness of breath worsens with exertion
Should I be worried about coffee ground emesis and other symptoms?
What is going on and is there something you can do to help me feel better?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious with all these symptoms happening at once, especially the coffee ground emesis and worsening shortness of breath. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your mental status—such as increased confusion or difficulty staying awake—during episodes when your breathing becomes more rapid (tachypnea) or when you experience fevers?

remedi_labels.value: changes in mental status (increased confusion or difficulty staying awake)

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Yes, actually, I have noticed that when my breathing gets more rapid—like during those tachypnea episodes—or when I have a fever, I do feel more confused and it’s harder to stay awake. Sometimes it feels like everything gets kind of fuzzy, and I just want to close my eyes. It’s a little scary, honestly.

Is that something that happens with hypoxia? I’m just not sure what’s causing all these symptoms to happen at the same time. Should I be worried about my mental status changing like this? And is there anything you can do to help me feel more comfortable or get some relief?

remedi_labels.value: should I be worried about mental status changes

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with these changes in your mental status and the involuntary movements you described. Based on your symptoms of somnolence, confusion, and right arm involuntary movements, I’d like to clarify—have you experienced any new weakness, numbness, or difficulty moving your right arm or leg during these episodes, which could suggest a neurological change?

remedi_labels.value: new weakness in right arm or leg
numbness in right arm or leg
difficulty moving right arm or leg

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… now that you mention it, I think there has been some weakness in my right arm, especially when those involuntary movements happen. Sometimes it feels a bit numb too, and it’s harder to grip symptoms or move it the way I want. My right leg feels weaker as well, but I thought maybe that was just because of my old femur fracture. I haven’t noticed any complete loss of movement, but it’s definitely not normal for me.

Is this something that could be related to a neurological problem? I’ve had TIAs in the past, so I’m a little worried about that. Should I be concerned about these symptoms coming back? And is there anything you can do to help with the weakness and discomfort? I just want to feel better and get some relief from all of this.

remedi_labels.value: difficulty gripping or moving right arm

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially given your history of TIAs and these new symptoms of somnolence, right arm weakness, and involuntary movements. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I want to assess for any acute neurological changes—have you experienced any difficulty with speech, facial drooping, or changes in vision during these episodes?

Let me think… Actually, I haven’t really noticed any facial drooping, and I don’t think my speech has changed much—at least, no one’s mentioned it to me. My vision’s been a little blurry at times, but I just thought maybe that was from being tired or the fevers. Should I be worried about these neurological symptoms? With my history of TIAs, I get nervous when anything like this comes up.

Is there something specific you’re looking for with these symptoms? And is there anything you can do to help me feel more comfortable? I just want to make sure I’m not missing something serious.

remedi_labels.value: specific symptoms doctor is looking for

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially given your history of TIAs and these new neurological symptoms. Based on your description of somnolence, right-sided weakness, involuntary movements, and recent episodes of coffee ground emesis, my assessment is focused on possible causes such as infection, metabolic disturbances, or neurological events. Have you noticed any new or worsening headaches, or any recent falls or trauma that could be related to your current symptoms?

Well, um… I haven’t had any new or really bad headpains, just the usual pains I get sometimes. And I don’t remember any recent falls or trauma, at least nothing out of the ordinary for me. My right leg’s still pain from that old femur fracture, but nothing new has happened to it.

I appreciate you explaining what you’re looking for with infection, metabolic disturbances, or neurological events. With all these symptoms—like the somnolence, right-sided weakness, involuntary movements, and that coffee ground emesis—I just feel really uncomfortable and a bit scared. Is there something serious going on? Should I be worried about infection or another TIA? And is there anything you can do to help me feel more comfortable while you figure this out? I just want some relief from all of this.

I can understand why you’d be anxious with these symptoms and your medical history, especially given the somnolence, right-sided weakness, involuntary movements, and coffee ground emesis. Based on my assessment, your symptoms could be related to an underlying infection (possibly sepsis), metabolic disturbance, or even a neurological event, all of which require close monitoring and supportive care. While we continue our clinical evaluation and supportive treatments to keep you comfortable—including oxygen for hypoxia and medications for pain and nausea—have you noticed any worsening of your gastroindiagnostic evaluationinal symptoms, such as increased abdominal pain or further episodes of dark vomit?

remedi_labels.value: worsening of gastrointestinal symptoms such as increased abdominal pain or further episodes of dark vomit

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for explaining all of that to me. Well, um… I have had a little more abdominal pain lately—it’s kind of a dull pain, nothing really sharp, but it’s definitely been more noticeable since all these other symptoms started. And yes, I did have another episode of dark vomit—coffee ground emesis, like you said—a couple nights ago. It really scared me, especially with the fevers and chills I’ve been having.

I just feel so uncomfortable, and honestly, I’m worried about what’s causing all of this. Is sepsis something that can happen with these symptoms? And is there anything you can do to help with the pain and nausea while you’re figuring symptoms out? I’d really like some relief if possible.
